speaker: James
text: [dry] The Weimar Republic, 1932. German defence spending, less than one percent of GDP. Seven years later, it was twenty-three percent. That's faster than paying off a car loan.

speaker: Elena
text: Oh, come on. You can't start with Hitler. That's a historical outlier, not a pattern.

speaker: James
text: Except it is the pattern. The article details five prior European rearmament cycles. Each one followed a devastating war, a period of disarmament, then a new threat. And then...

speaker: Elena
text: And then war. You're saying it's inevitable this time too?

speaker: James
text: Not inevitable, but highly probable without significant change. Europe is currently spending EUR 800 billion on defence. Poland is over four percent of GDP already.

speaker: Elena
text: Right, because Russia invaded Ukraine. That's a direct, immediate threat. It's not some abstract historical rhythm.

speaker: James
text: But the peace dividend of the last three decades systematically dismantled Europe's industrial capacity. That's the key. Remember the EU couldn't deliver one million artillery shells?

speaker: Elena
text: That's a logistical problem, not a structural one.

speaker: James
text: [emphatic] It is absolutely structural. Rheinmetall was producing 70,000 shells a year. Russia, three million. That's a capacity problem, not a logistics problem.

speaker: Elena
text: So you're saying Europe just let its guard down? Foolishly?

speaker: James
text: We assumed Russia was defanged, America would always guarantee security, and economic interdependence made war impossible. All wrong.

speaker: Elena
text: That's a convenient reading of the data. We prioritised social spending, healthcare, education. That's hardly foolish.

speaker: James
text: No, it's just a trade-off. We got welfare states. We lost the ability to defend them. That's the reality.

speaker: Elena
text: [frustrated] But this isn't the 1930s. We have NATO. We have the EU. There are institutions now.

speaker: James
text: Institutions are only as strong as their members' commitment. Spain, for instance, capping defence at 2.1% of GDP. Poland looks at that and wonders what NATO actually means.

speaker: Elena
text: Wait, really? Spain isn't committing to the 3.5%?

speaker: James
text: No. The article makes it clear: there's a geography of fear. Countries closer to Russia spend more.

speaker: Elena
text: So, divisions within the alliance. That's hardly a recipe for stability, is it?

speaker: James
text: Exactly. And then there's the fragmentation. Twenty-seven national armies, twenty different types of tanks, twenty-nine frigates. The US has one of each.

speaker: Elena
text: That's just wasteful. So this EUR 800 billion won't even buy us proper defence?

speaker: James
text: Not if 78% of procurement goes outside Europe, mostly to the US. We're paying America to defend us, while talking about strategic autonomy. It's absurd.

speaker: Elena
text: I think you're overstating the fragmentation problem. The EU has joint procurement mechanisms. They're trying to fix it.

speaker: James
text: Joint programmes like the Eurofighter or the A400M? Years late, billions over budget. Every government wants its own industry to benefit. Local jobs, not pan-European efficiency.

speaker: Elena
text: Okay, fine. That's harder to argue with than I expected. The industrial policy angle is... sticky.

speaker: James
text: [thoughtful] But there is a twist. This time could be different. Not because we're better, but because of necessity.

speaker: Elena
text: Go on. This sounds like a stretch.

speaker: James
text: If Europe wants genuine military capability, it *has* to integrate. Standardise, rationalise, share logistics. Like the US military after the Civil War.

speaker: Elena
text: So, rearmament could force deeper integration? A European army?

speaker: James
text: Precisely. Not out of idealism, but out of sheer economic pressure. When you're spending five percent of GDP, you can't afford duplication.

speaker: Elena
text: Well... that's a fascinating, if rather dark, way to achieve unity. It's definitely not what I thought you'd say.

speaker: James
text: It would be the first time the pattern was genuinely broken. A collective defence, too strong to challenge, too integrated to misuse.

speaker: Elena
text: But you mentioned earlier, the weapons you build for one threat get used for another. What about that 'North African Threat' we discussed? Or China?

speaker: James
text: That's the enduring danger. Military-industrial complexes acquire their own momentum. Eisenhower warned us.

speaker: Elena
text: So we could end up with a hugely powerful, integrated European military... pointed at the wrong problem in twenty years?

speaker: James
text: Or creating new problems. That's the uncomfortable truth of rearmament, historically.

speaker: Elena
text: [conceding] So it's a gamble. A necessary one, perhaps, but a gamble all the same.

speaker: James
text: A gamble on the most valuable anomaly in European history. We've lived our entire lives in an exception.

speaker: Elena
text: The 80 years of major power peace. You mean that?

speaker: James
text: That's it. For 400 years prior, major wars every 30-40 years. We've mistaken the exception for the rule.

speaker: Elena
text: The bill has arrived, as the article says. And the answer defines the century.
